Her first apology wasn't even, you know, sufficient or good, she didn't apologize directly to the President, you know, or to her families, sort of to her fans, kind of, so she was not sincere but she should have even left it and now, she has made it even worse by trying to go forward and pretend that she was a victim, even though it was her own personal choice and combat that she engaged and that was pre-planned.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then why the Lisa Bloom lawyer stunt? Like, what is she doing there?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, that's what they do. Some has agreed, you come forward, and they have the lawyer by them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Even if you don't plan to file a lawsuit?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Listen.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who is she going to sue?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But why do you have a lawyer?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They do this so they go forward --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Anytime we bring a lawyer into the situation, it makes people back off a little bit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I need an attorney to go forward and have a press conference because I have a legal regress, to create the appearance I think that she has some kind of action.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what bothers me though is I think the whole ideal of civil discourse is obviously at no web in our country. But this woman is a provocateur. She has been thrown off "The View." She has been thrown off-- some people say she's been thrown off Ellen DeGeneres because she says obnoxious things to get attention. Not funny. She's not an artist. She's not made for --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you know what, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She's just being --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But the press machine knew what she was all about. She was on in any red carpet, and made a sex joke about Jesus.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She was kicked off an E red carpet for making inappropriate joke over 10-year-old Dakota Fanning.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She was absolutely had to gave her paycheck back to CNN at one point because she used the f word when she was talking about a six-year-old boy. So, everybody saw what she was all about and they enabled her.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And why did they keep her on?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then when she finally crosses, then everybody distances themselves. It is very convenient.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I wish that the right would do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, what? I think that it would be really interesting is, if Donald Trump tweeted -- you should tell him this tomorrow morning when he calls her.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't advise him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He should tweet. Forgive her. Don't destroy her career. She's learned a lesson. And it will change the narrative on the Paris accords and it will blow people's mind and it is actually real, easy, simple win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump takes the high road.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow! I liked it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what, she apologized and let's let her live her life.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is actually one of the best things that a leader can teach you is, the power of forgiveness.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Which is?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In the short-term, let it go. I mean, that would be amazing. She would be very lucky if that happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Unless Jesse is right. And actually she thinks she advanced her career.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Absolute right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think she wants to keep it going. She wants to be agreed and that's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think she wants your seat, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to sit next to her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Coming up, President Trump takes on the world by pulling out of the Paris climate. Of course. And some folks are in full melt down mode. We will show you after this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is President Trump versus the world. The planet is erupted in full blown hysteria over the President's decision to pull America out of the Paris climate path. Landmarks and city halls will lit up in green last night across the world in some cities here at home in support of the environmental accord. The President calls it an unfair deal that hurts the American taxpayers. The global elite disagree.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN WILLIAMS, NBC NEWS
utterances.utterance: On a sunny day on the Rose Garden, what could be defined and construed as a dark speech and as you go through it, more like four or five dark speeches in there.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALI, HOUSE MINORITY LEADER
utterances.utterance: The Bible tells us to minister to the needs of God the creation as an act of worship, to ignore those needs is to dishonor the God who made us. And that is just what we are doing. By walking away from this accord.

utterances.speaker: GOV. JERRY BROWN, D-CALIFORNIA
utterances.utterance: This is a crazy decision, it's against the facts. It's against science, it's against reality itself. We know that we have to decarbonize our future. If we don't, it's a whore, people are going to die.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so people are going to die. Greg, the Democrats has said that the President's healthcare plan will kill people. The President's climate plan will kill people and now his budget will kill people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They never were read that story by their parents.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, Shelly Steele has this great phrase called poetic, truth, it's false truth that action replaces real truth. If you were to ask any of these people. What is the global mean temperature, right? They would not know. It is 59 degrees. And then if you asked them, if it is warmer or colder than it was 7,000 years ago. They would not know. It is actually cooler now than it was 7,000 years ago.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Cooler. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When they come and they tell you the statistics about being the hottest temperature or the hottest year ever. If you asked them what the increase was, they wouldn't be able to tell you that every single year that there's an increase, it is within the margin of error, meaning it is not increasing. So, those are called real truths. The poetic truths is the chaos and the hysteria because that plays to the media. And it makes you feel so important. And you get to punish America for being so successful by doing these stupid deals. But if you read the facts about the high temperatures, about the reality of our past, it is all BS.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow. Well, I am trying not to -- I don't want to repeat it yesterday. Do you want to respond to that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I feel that he made a comment. I'm getting fired up inside.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's green.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I got to get the green house.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan the green.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Because I just think, you know, Greg, you are talking about when the earth was created and fires bloomed everywhere. That's what you said. That's what you said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh my God! I said 7,000 years ago in a different era. I didn't say when the earth began.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Come on, Juan! You're a religious man.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When did the earth begin?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just tell you this. If you still want to fight with NASA and with the National -- but let me just say --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, man. You are so desperate. You are so desperate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because you know what, I know the facts. And you don't have the facts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just gave you facts. You give the opinion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what you give me? You give me stand and arrogance and stubborn headed --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Okay. Let me ask you, what is the global mean temperature?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It doesn't matter? It does matter?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You just told me so I can repeat what you say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't even remember what you said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't care what he said either.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't even know the extreme weather changes. You know nothing about this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Excuse me. Excuse me. Let me just tell you something.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: One last word because we have to move on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because you know what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You just got destroyed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. If it was bad breath, yes. But let me just say this. When you look at the reality and I don't think there is any question that temperatures -- let me speak!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you're condescending.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not condescending.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You said, when you look at the facts. I stated the facts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is not going anywhere. This is not going anywhere. KG?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But he didn't state the facts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I did!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is actually isn't about real climate science, this is about money. And it's about who would contribute to these funds and obviously, the UN and other European countries are upset because we were supposed to contribute. The American taxpayer with an obligation to contribute $3 billion for this. Why should we have to pay this? Like, this was not a good deal to begin with. It doesn't mean that President Trump will not examine this issue and look at the science behind it and decide what kind of agreement that he feels comfortable that is good for America to be a part of. Not one that places an undue burden on our country and our economy but one that is fair and equal and proportionate as it relates to our obligations monetarily, et cetera.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me say a quick point here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really quick, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Very quick, I just want to say that major American oil companies, major American companies like Mars and major American cities and states are all saying, this was a mistake, it will hurt our economy, it will not help us.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The candy bar?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: First time Juan agreed with the oil company.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wait. The candy bar?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Even the Mars people.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Major oil companies and Mars.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I am telling you, I just want to mention a few but Hewlett Packard, I could go on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana, let me just ask you a question. Because I am getting annoyed with this talking points from the left. They're saying, all these other countries are doing it so why can't America, it's like, you know, when a kid gets caught smoking cigarettes and all my friends are doing it mom, it's not an excuse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that the national leaders who supported the Paris agreement, including President Obama had their domestic politics in mind. Okay? So, that helped President Obama with his domestic politics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Uh-hm.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump also had a political interests in selling yesterday's move for his domestic audience.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Okay. Macron today, he's talking about the world and really, he's a new leader and this is all remember, this all goes back to domestic politics and it appears to me that basically what we are doing is nullifying an insignificant agreement that was nonbinding. And so now what you have is what I think that the leaders did, they got to the Paris agreement because they couldn't get anything else. They couldn't get anything binding. None of them sent it too, well, I'm sorry, President Obama didn't send it to our Congress because they wouldn't have approved it. That's the same with Kyoto. So, they tried to go around that. And we basically are walking America down a path to be committed to these other agreements in terms of the economics. Now, I don't think that the White House did a good job in explaining that in the lead up to it. Because the whole story was about the drama, will he or really not?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If you're going to take this side, I'm going to take that, all became about the -- intrigue instead of explaining to the people why exactly the economics didn't make sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Trump did a very good job explaining that, but it was all about the Trump announcement.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I got to respond to that. Also the climate clerics failed to persuade as well. Their arrogance prevented them from explaining the mechanics of this accord. If you explained it better. Also, I mean, Juan, I think that we can agree on this. We have to continue look at the science and invest in R and D. Do you not agree with that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And that means, funny, cheaper renewable energy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm talking about. The economy is, it's the economics that matters.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And by the way, and this went through and President Trump didn't withdraw from the Paris accord, we would be seeing endless lawsuits where people are bringing cases for forcing the United States government to implement and comply with certain sections of this. The Ninth Circuit, the Fourth Circuit --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Juan, because he cares about the environment is a walk back to Washington, D.C.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes. Yes. Let me just quickly respond to Greg and say, look --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Quickly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: American business leaders wrote to Donald Trump, he is supposed to be the businessman and he said this is something we want, it is good for American business, good for the American economy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He can make a better deal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, he can do a better deal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: President Trump's controversial travel ban has now reached the Supreme Court. Will the justices backed a safety measure or block it. Up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. President Trump's temporary travel ban is now in the hands of the Supreme Court. Justices could design in days whether to let this stay on the President's revise executive order to halt travel from six mostly Muslim countries. The White House insists it's necessary and constitutional.

utterances.speaker: SEAN SPICER, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: So, last night, we asked the Supreme Court to hear this important case. And are confident that the President's executive orders while within his lawful authority to keep the national safe and protect our communities from terrorism. The President's not required to admit people from countries that sponsor or shelter terrorism.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Dana, what do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I've been saying for a while that I thought that the White House should do this because especially after Neil Gorsuch got sat on the Supreme Court, that this issue is too important to leave to, you know, how long it would usually take for -- I'm not crying. I don't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're crying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sorry. It is spilling out. Because the Fourth Circuit just came out, and said no. The Ninth Circuit has said, no. And so now this is the time I think for the White House to ask for expedited review by the Supreme Court since now they are nine justices and just get some clarity. And whatever, whatever the decision is, then move on from there. If they have to revise and rewrite what they want to do, so that it is constitutional, great. And if they don't, then you can say, the supreme law of the land has said that this is constitutional and they can go forward and implement.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think it's a perfect timing, it's appropriate and this is what they were supposed to do, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think the important thing here is that we are having a conversation about something that's really important. The conversation goes back if you start calling people xenophobic or Islamophobic because that tells everyone that you're living in the past, that -- a past where this apocalyptic threats didn't exist, so when you're actually worried about Islamic terrorism, you're somehow racist, you're basically a barnacle on society. You're living off us. We no longer should be -- led a fabricated guilt over a law that somehow we are flawed to prevent us from protecting ourselves from an imminent apocalyptic threat. So in a sense, we have to divorce ourselves from liberal guilt and have no problem with saying no terrorists allowed, no Islamists allowed.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Jesse, what do you think? The timing and also the ban.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think it's good timing. I think the anti-Trump media narrative for the first 100 days is going to totally flip in the next 200 days. They said this travel ban was going to be held up in the courts. Looks like it's probably going to be a 5-4 decision in the Supreme Court. They said the president could get legislation through congress on peace, health care reform, and tax cuts. They also said that he was colluding with Russia. Now, all these new investigations and subpoenas making the Obama spying scandal that much more important. So, you know, there are checks and balances with these things. Eventually, the constitution wins in (ph) Article 1 Section of the constitution congress says the power to regulate immigration and in 52, they pass all empowering the president to deny entry into the U.S. any class of citizens considered to be detrimental to the interests of the United States.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well within the authority of the president of the United States, Juan, so now what?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was just so fascinated, Jesse. That was unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was stunned. I didn't know anybody thought that the Trump administration was on pace with replace -- repeal and replace or tax reform. Really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you will get these things done by...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm just -- I'm glad for you. I just don't think the rest of the world is on that page. And, guess what, Greg.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg, there is a big difference between being somehow inhibited by (inaudible) guilt or something liberal guild and history. The reality of history being learning from mistakes you have made in the past.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We have.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The judge in the Ninth Circuit said that the Trump order drips with religious intolerance, animus, and discrimination.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know, he's not silly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah, gee. So I think...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Conflicts sound legal arguments.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah, religious discrimination.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's not -- that's not...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are complaining Islamic terror with Islam because you're saying if you want to ban terrorism, that somehow...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, that's not what I'm doing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's exactly what you did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what Donald Trump does when he said...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, he separated it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ... there are countries with Muslim majority...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They embrace him. Fifty Islamic countries, they embrace him. They are fighting -- more Muslims are killed by Islamic terror.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fine, but I'm just telling you, in the United States, we do not discriminate against anybody based on...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just tell you. The most likely outcome right now since the court has stopped hearing oral arguments for the season is that this gets held over and decided in September, I'm not sure that makes anybody...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You think they are going to do something...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think they will do it sooner because I think that the national -- it's the interest of national security and that the president needs it as the nation actually needs an answer on this, whether it goes forward against the president so they can clarify it, not just for Americans, but also for those traveling from those countries.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They should just call it a tax.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They got Obamacare, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think they are going to reconcile.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to explain that to Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Okay, ahead, the ladies at "the View" can't seem to tell the difference between American democracy and the Taliban. We are going to explain it simply to them next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness. Arguments over music. The hosts at "The View" have a way of getting themselves in the headlines this time with their strange (inaudible) on the Trump administration plan to reverse an ObamaCare mandate requiring employers provide workers with insurance covering birth control.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You can't (inaudible) religion.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: They know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: (inaudible) other people's rights.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Well, that is done all of the time. Look, how is this different from the Taliban with all these rollbacks and all the things that we hear? What is the difference between us and the people we are fighting?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Nothing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: That's something. It's to keep women down also.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, a heads up to "The View" crew on what it is like to live as a woman or a girl under Taliban and Sharia law. Banned from going to school or studying, banned from working, banned from leaving the house without a male chaperon, banned from showing their skin in public, banned from being involved in politics, can't even speak publicly. Wow!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sexual mutilation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow, I don't want to go there. You can talk about it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: If they are making these kinds of comparison, saying it, likening it to the Taliban, it just goes to show you the outrageous nature of their claims.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, let's take it seriously for a second, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm taking it seriously.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM
utterances.utterance: No, I can't -- it's hard for me to take it seriously. I mean, there is no comparison to Sharia law. But what they are saying is, if it's a religious basis for President Trump's decision, then people who have one side of religious belief can enforce it on everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, the actual principle or doctrine is to not discriminate against a certain religion and to embrace religious freedom and liberty and not make people adhere to something that they are opposed to on the basis of their religion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But the of course, Jesse, what they're saying is, you would be forced as an employee to live under the doctrine of your employer. By the way, Donald Trump has said all along, he believes in birth control. He has no problem with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I don't have any problem with birth control either but if you're a practicing or devoted Catholic, why should you have to provide that to people that work for you. And if you are working for someone like them, you are probably reading off of the same script when it comes to that stuff. You know, I don't want to knock "The View" because I might read a book one day.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I like Jedediah a lot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But I will say though, some of the things they say, it's not real analysis. It's like, they throw the word Taliban or Nazi or Hitler into word salad and then the audience cheers and then Fox News run to the cliff and then they get clicks online. It's not real political analysis. And then I go on the show and promote a book.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
